reasoning: A lawyer's first step is to determine if the Consumer Rights Act 2015 is the correct piece of legislation for the client's problem[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 1(1) of the Act confirms that it applies to agreements between a trader and a consumer for the supply of goods[cite: 44, 47].
The lawyer must then establish that the parties involved fit the legal definitions required by the Act[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 2(3) defines a 'consumer' as an individual acting for purposes outside their trade or profession[cite: 67].
Section 2(2) defines a 'trader' as a person acting for purposes related to their trade or business[cite: 66].
The lawyer needs to classify the item purchased to ensure it falls within the Act's scope[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 2(8) defines 'goods' as any tangible moveable items, which includes a travel adapter[cite: 81].
The lawyer must identify the specific statutory right that has been breached[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 9(1) implies a term into the contract that goods must be of 'satisfactory quality'[cite: 176].
Sections 9(2) and 9(3) clarify that satisfactory quality includes fitness for purpose and freedom from defects, which the non-working adapter clearly breaches[cite: 177, 181, 183, 185].
After establishing a breach, the lawyer must determine the available remedies[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 19(3) grants the consumer a 'short-term right to reject' for goods that do not conform to the contract[cite: 339, 340].
Section 20(1) and 20(5) outline that this right is exercised by the consumer indicating their rejection to the trader[cite: 383, 388].
Section 22(3) specifies that this right must be exercised within 30 days of receiving the goods[cite: 461].
The final step is to confirm the specific outcome of the remedy, in this case, the refund[cite: 4667, 4671].
Section 20(7)(a) mandates that upon rejection, the trader has a duty to provide a refund[cite: 391, 392].
Section 20(10) specifies that the consumer is entitled to receive back the same amount of money they paid[cite: 400].
Section 20(15) requires the refund to be processed without undue delay and within 14 days of the trader agreeing to it[cite: 406].
